Articles.Content:
What's the difference between 'landed' and 'splashed down'? Because !SCIENCE! cares.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-28T02:40:56Z" title="07/28/2015 02:40  AM" data-short="8 yr">July 28, 2015</time> by ibanix**
Where you do it. Landed is on land. Splashed down is in water.
It is possible to splash down on land. At least, there is a science entry for every Kerbin biome for 'splashed down'. There's also one for 'landed at Kerbin's water'.

You cannot splash down on land. You can however be splashed down (in water) in a biome that is not the "water" biome. You can also be landed (yes, on land) in the water biome if you look hard enough or get lucky.

Not a dumb question at all. It's actually quite a complex answer.
Interesting! Any hints on where one might manage these oddball splash landings?

[http://www.kerbalmaps.com/](http://www.kerbalmaps.com/)

Go jump in a lake! (Hehe, not the sort of thing I expected to be writing on the KSP forum)

I have to throw in a couple things here:

1. If contracts are your kind of thing, [Field Research](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/123892) has some contracts that will give you suggested waypoints for these hard-to-find combinations.
2. You can also get landed on Water by EVA'ing and standing on your ship. You can get this for non-EVA experiments by landing on a ship (or if you're clever, build a ship with a bottom section that floats, and decouple a top section with loads of experiments - FOR SCIENCE).

> 
> Interesting! Any hints on where one might manage these oddball splash landings?

The Island airfield *used* to be the Water biome. Haven't looked lately.

\*loads a cargo plane with a science rover\*
